>> Thanks, everyone, for coming.
I'm really excited to introduce our speaker

3.text:
this afternoon, Lauren Weber, author of,
"In Cheap We Trust: The story of a misunderstood

9.text:
American virtue.”
It seems like this book couldn't have come

12.text:
at a better time, as the recession has caused
Americans to reconsider their tendency to

16.text:
consume rather than save -- to enlarge their
debts instead of tightening the belt.

22.text:
Lauren begins her book talking about a different
kind of American -- her father -- who kept

27.text:
their Connecticut home at 50 degrees during
winters, used hand signals instead of turn

32.text:
signals on their car, and taught his children
how to ration toilet paper, although this

37.text:
last idea didn't really work out.
Lauren writes that she resented this at first,

41.text:
but came to understand the virtues her father
had passed down to her.

45.text:
Last month, she told the New York Times, "I
like the word 'cheap'. I embrace it.

49.text:
To me, it really means self-determination
and freedom."

52.text:
Lauren was a staff reporter at Reuters and
Newsday, and has written for the New York

58.text:
Times and the Los Angeles Times.
She currently lives in New York City.

62.text:
And I got to say, she really practices what
she preaches.

64.text:
Despite not being a local, Lauren used BART
and Caltrain to get here from the East Bay.

69.text:
So, no fancy car for her.
After Lauren talks and reads from the book

74.text:
a little bit, please feel free to come up
to the mic -- there's one mic I believe -- and

79.text:
ask her questions.
So please give a warm welcome to Lauren Weber.

83.text:
Lauren Weber: Thank you. And thanks Katie
for introducing me and for inviting me.

91.text:
I was telling her when my publicist sent along
the e-mail inviting me to come to Google,

97.text:
I was like, "Oh, my God, I feel like I've
made it.”

101.text:
So, some of you probably do too for being
able to work here and eat that food every

104.text:
day.
When I told friends I was coming, they all

107.text:
said, "Can you eat in the cafeteria?”
And I will report back that I did.

113.text:
So, thanks again for having me.
I sense from the composition of the audience

118.text:
that cheapness is a topic that resonates more
for men than for women maybe.

121.text:
[laughter] And I was also telling Katie that,
after some of the media stuff that I've done,

130.text:
including the New York Times -- the interview
with the Frugal Traveler Blog of the New York

135.text:
Times -- I have gotten a few, very random
e-mails from men proposing to me.

139.text:
[laughter] And usually they say -- there have
been three marriage proposals I think -- and

144.text:
usually they say, "Women keep breaking up
with me, because they call me too cheap.”

149.text:
So, they seem to hope that I could, you know,
embrace that part of them.

154.text:
So I'm always happy to report, to tell them
that I actually do have a boyfriend, and he's

160.text:
even cheaper than me.
He can't pass a dumpster without climbing

163.text:
into it.
So, yeah. I met him when I interviewed him

167.text:
for the book.
You know, we're pretty well-matched.

172.text:
Katie mentioned my dad -- and this is actually
the first audience that I've spoken to that

175.text:
didn't include at least one person who knew
my father -- and my dad did in fact, keep

182.text:
the heat at 50 degrees when I was growing
up in Connecticut.

184.text:
He is an economist.
He taught economics for 40 years at the Coast

187.text:
Guard Academy in New London, Connecticut.
And so, he's an economist in every sense of

192.text:
the word -- professionally, and then, in the
fact that he economizes on everything.

197.text:
He did keep the heat at 50 degrees, and I
would do my homework at the kitchen table

200.text:
wearing hats and scarves and with my hands
on the stove after dinner to try to keep warm.

205.text:
He tried to ration our family's toilet paper,
which fortunately, he couldn't figure out

211.text:
a way to monitor it.
So this was long before webcams.

215.text:
[laughter] And so, he fortunately gave up
on that one.

219.text:
He does, in fact, use hand signals out the
window of the car rather than using his turning

224.text:
signal, because I think he thinks this way,
he preserves the bulb in the light on the

229.text:
car.
He also insisted on washing all of our dishes

233.text:
by hand and he didn't use soap.
He used cold water and no soap.

238.text:
And eventually we figured this out and realized
this was why the knives and forks were usually

243.text:
encrusted with food.
You know, my dad is -- you could call him

248.text:
'compulsively cheap'.
So I grew up my whole life trying to figure

251.text:
him out.
And, like Katie said, I also complained bitterly

256.text:
about it.
My mother did too.

259.text:
In fact, while I was working on the book,
I interviewed both my parents, and I asked

262.text:
my mom, "How did you manage to coexist for
so long with Dad?”

266.text:
They're still married 44 years later.
And she said, "I should have divorced him

270.text:
a long time ago.”
And it turned out they had had an argument

274.text:
about something else that morning.
So that's partly why there was a lot of acrimony

278.text:
there.
But she said, "Don't tell that story.

280.text:
Tell the story of how I once packed all three
of you up," -- I have a brother and a sister

285.text:
-- "and threatened to take you all to a motel,
because the house was so cold.”

289.text:
And apparently, she did get us all to get
our homework into our bags and packed some

294.text:
clothes for school the next day.
And I think my dad at that point realized

299.text:
that the hotel would be more expensive; and
so, the heat went up.

304.text:
I did complain about this much of my childhood.
And then, when I got older -- and especially

309.text:
as I started to support myself -- I realized
that A, I had kind of involuntarily turned

314.text:
into my father.
When I moved to Seattle, I moved in with my

318.text:
boyfriend there, and I wouldn't let him turn
the heat above sixty degrees.

321.text:
So I was not quite as extreme, but I was still
a bit of a fascist about the heat.

327.text:
And I also found myself, you know, walking
30 blocks to save two dollars on the subway

332.text:
when I moved to New York.
And doing all kinds of weird things to save

337.text:
money.
I realized I had kind of turned into my father.

340.text:
And I also strangely realized that I appreciated
what he had taught me.

344.text:
He had given me some important lessons on
how to live within my means and on the value

349.text:
of doing that.
And when I was able to sort of take a step

353.text:
back from it, I also was able to appreciate
the fact that he is one of the most generous

357.text:
people I have ever known.
He gives a lot of money to charity as well

362.text:
as time.
He's always volunteering for a lot of different

364.text:
organizations he believes in.
So, he gives money to anybody who needs it.

368.text:
I think he has a real sense of his own good
fortune in life.

371.text:
And he also sent three kids to very expensive,
private universities and never uttered a word

377.text:
of complaint.
And, you know, what I came to realize over

381.text:
time was that my dad wasn't just cheap in
a crazy way.

384.text:
He actually really had his priorities in order
and knew what was important to him.

389.text:
And that he may have like gotten crazy if
you were in the shower for more than three

393.text:
minutes.
There would always be a knock on the door.

395.text:
But, you know, he really knew what his values
were.

400.text:
And I started to really respect that about
him.

402.text:
And also feel grateful that he taught me how
to live within my means.

406.text:
So that's kind of the personal angle to the
story.

410.text:
And then the other angle is that I'm a business
reporter by training -- and I worked for Reuters

417.text:
for a few years and then for Newsday, the
paper for Long Island -- and I was really

422.text:
interested in the macroeconomics of these
issues of spending and saving.

425.text:
I wanted to understand what it meant that
Americans had such a low savings rate, which

429.text:
in the last decade or so has been around two
percent.

432.text:
In 2005, it actually dipped into negative
territory for the first time since the Great

437.text:
Depression, which means Americans were spending
more than we were earning.

440.text:
So I wanted to understand what that meant,
what it meant that Americans had so much debt.

445.text:
We lived in what another historian has called,
"The age of leverage."

450.text:
And, you know, what the implications of all
that were.

453.text:
So I kind of brought both the personal side
and my professional interest to writing the

458.text:
book.
So that's kind of like the background for

461.text:
why it resonated so much for me.
And then, the moment when the idea for the

467.text:
book actually came to me, I was sitting on
the subway underneath Brooklyn.

471.text:
I live in Queens. So I was on the G Train.
Anybody here who's a New Yorker knows -- it

475.text:
goes between Brooklyn and Queens.
And I was reading another book.

479.text:
It's called "The Progress Paradox," by Gregg
Easterbrook.

482.text:
It's not a well-known book, but I had seen
it and was interested, because it basically

486.text:
asks a question, "Why if America is the most
affluent nation that's ever existed, Why are

492.text:
there such high levels of depression and anxiety
and unhappiness here?”

496.text:
And there wasn't anything in particular in
the book that sparked this question, but I

500.text:
suddenly looked up and thought to myself,
"What happened to thrift in America?”

504.text:
It seemed to me that maybe was some connection
between this hypermaterialistic culture that

510.text:
we live in and these very high rates of unhappiness
and depression.

516.text:
So that became kind of the animating question
of the book was, "What happened to thrift

521.text:
in America?”
You know, it used to be an important American

524.text:
value.
And it's a part of our national mythology

527.text:
of who we are and who we were.
Ben Franklin and all that.

530.text:
-- Did this just go off? Is it still on?
Can everybody still hear me? Okay.

536.text:
Yeah something just happened to the sound.
Is it back on? Okay. I think it's back on.

542.text:
-- So yeah. This was once an important American
value and it seemed that it was no longer

548.text:
a part of our sense of who we are today.
So the book has a lot of history in it and

555.text:
about two-thirds of it is history.
And it sort of follows this question of, "What

559.text:
happened to thrift in America?”
And I kind of came up with two different and

562.text:
almost contradictory answers.
One part of that is, On some level we actually

567.text:
were never a thrifty nation to begin with.
It's a myth that we've sustained about ourselves

574.text:
for a long time.
For most of our history, Americans were frugal

578.text:
because they had to be.
It was a question of necessity much more than

581.text:
choice.
You know, the economy was terribly unregulated.

588.text:
It's all based on booms and busts for much
of the 1700s and 1800s.

592.text:
And so, people had no choice but to live extremely
cheaply.

596.text:
And this was a time also when any dress you
wore was something that you had stayed up

601.text:
until 11 o'clock stitching by candlelight,
or any quart of firewood that you burned was

606.text:
wood that you yourself had gone out and cut
down.

609.text:
So people also had a really great appreciation
for the value of the things in their lives.

615.text:
Now, we live in a world where we sit on chairs.
We have no idea where they came from, or who

619.text:
made them.
Most of us eat food that we have no idea where

623.text:
it came from.
Maybe not here at Google but.

627.text:
And you know, so back in those days, people
were deeply connected to the resources that

632.text:
they used, and they had no money.
So as a result, they were probably what we

636.text:
would consider 'frugal' today, very resourceful,
very

639.text:
-- oh, it just went off again I think. There
it is. --

644.text:
-- very resourceful, very prudent and cautious
about spending.

647.text:
But, if you look at it in history, any time
Americans had more, that their incomes went

652.text:
up, or had more access to credit -- and that
was often really the key to it -- they spent.

658.text:
So, you know, I often say, "Thrift was a virtue
Americans couldn't wait to relinquish.”

662.text:
Whether it was installment plans in the 1850's
to buy a sewing machine, or the first credit

667.text:
cards in the 1950's.
As soon as Americans had greater access to

672.text:
cheap money, they took advantage of it.
And you know, as much as we like to think

678.text:
of ourselves as having been frugal back then,
often again, it was economic necessity and

683.text:
sometimes political necessity.
So like, during the American Revolution, there

687.text:
were a lot of boycots of British products.
And you know, this is where we get the tea

692.text:
party from -- the Boston tea party.
And there was, what I would call, "conspicuous

697.text:
frugality" going on back then.
Ben Franklin, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams,

702.text:
all those guys were trying to get Americans
to stop buying imported goods.

705.text:
And, you know, townspeople would get up together
and sign petitions saying that they would

709.text:
never drink British tea.
They called it "poison.”

712.text:
They would say that they would only wear homespun
 -- which was coarse textiles made in America

717.text:
-- rather than silks and linens from Britain
and all that.

720.text:
As soon as the Revolution ended, all of that
well-meaning frugality sort of went out the

726.text:
window, and suddenly everybody wanted Rococo
furniture from France and these British ideals

731.text:
of gentility where flirting was practiced
as an art and everybody wanted to have a parlor

735.text:
with a piano and a tea set -- were very popular.
So thrift has been a virtue Americans have

742.text:
sort of taken on when it's convenient and
jettisoned when it was no longer necessary.

747.text:
So that was one of my answers was, We were
never a particularly thrifty nation.

752.text:
You know, that it was not necessarily -- it
was often more of a virtue that Americans

755.text:
admired than aspired to.
And then, the other answer -- which may seem

760.text:
a little bit contradictory -- is that, we
were kind of frugal in the sense that thrift

767.text:
was something that we admired, but then around
the middle of the 20th century, we really

773.text:
developed into a consumer society and this
was not just something that happened accidentally.

778.text:
It was practically an orchestrated effort
after World War II.

782.text:
World War II -- along with being a military
effort -- was also a gigantic stimulus plan.

788.text:
And after the Depression, it was the war that
put people back to work and created a lot

793.text:
of need for factories and for production and
manufacturing and stuff like that.

798.text:
And even before the war ended, there were
a lot of economists and politicians who were

804.text:
very concerned that, once the war was over,
there would be no engine for the economy.

809.text:
They were really worried that we would plunge
back into a Depression -- which was a very

813.text:
reasonable concern.
It was a traumatic event for many Americans.

817.text:
So, in the early 40's, you start to sort of
get this groundswell of public propaganda

825.text:
about how, "Once the war's over, we got to
start buying.

829.text:
Now, we're using all of our metal for shrapnel
 -- for bullets and stuff -- after the war

834.text:
is over, it's going to be for a dishwashers.”
And advertisers used that kind of language

839.text:
too.
In fact, I think it's not a coincidence that

842.text:
Scrooge McDuck -- who is Donald Duck's miserly
uncle -- appears in 1947.

848.text:
And I sort of date that as around the time
that frugality went from being a virtue and

854.text:
something that we looked up to and championed
to being sort of a punch line.

858.text:
It now became funny when people saved money.
They were miserly rather than frugal.

862.text:
It was no longer a virtue, it was an insult
 -- a punch line, an eccentricity, or a quirk.

870.text:
And, you know, it was all over the culture.
Brides Magazine did a story in -- I think

875.text:
it was the late 40's -- saying that newlyweds
should outfit their homes with brand name

879.text:
goods, not only because it would make their
houses look better, but because it would keep

883.text:
Americans at work.
This idea that it was patriotic to spend and

887.text:
that it was your civic duty to be a consumer
became very widespread.

891.text:
And it's something that I think Americans
have really, deeply internalized.

896.text:
And when I was a reporter at Newsday, I covered
retail for a few years, so I was always like

901.text:
ambushing shoppers in the middle of their
Christmas shopping and like jumping out from

906.text:
behind racks of clothes to ask them like,
what they were buying and why.

910.text:
And I can't even count the number of times
that people would sort of sheepishly laugh

915.text:
and tell me they were doing their part to
help the American economy.

918.text:
It's just an idea that we've now taken in
deeply.

922.text:
So it was interesting to me to sort of track
the history of that.

926.text:
I'm going to read a couple of -- and one thing
I also want to add is that -- when I started

935.text:
working on the book, a friend of mine said
that I should call it, "Thrift: A short history

939.text:
of a dying virtue.”
And the more that I talked to people, the

943.text:
more convinced I was that it wasn't dying
at all.

945.text:
In fact, it was alive and well.
And there are still thousands -- and probably

949.text:
millions -- of people living frugally by choice.
And you know, because everybody I talked to

954.text:
would say, "Oh, you've got to interview my
mother.”

956.text:
Or "my brother", or "my boss".
Or "my daughter". Or "my husband", often.

963.text:
And, you know, it was clear that there are
lots and lots of people living this way.

968.text:
So my feeling is that thrift is alive and
well, it just kind of went underground at

973.text:
a certain point.
Like I said, I sort of date that to that postwar

976.text:
period when we started getting the message
that we needed to keep shopping, otherwise

981.text:
we weren't good Americans.
And of course, September 11th was sort of

984.text:
the apogee of that idea when both Rudy Guiliani
and George Bush and countless others got up

990.text:
and told Americans to go out and spend.
It was the exact opposite message that Americans

994.text:
received in World War II, where the whole
idea was to sacrifice.

997.text:
So, I'm going to read a little bit from one
of my historical chapters, and then read a

1004.text:
little bit from one of the later chapters.
This chapter was one of my favorites to write.

1007.text:
It's called "Cheap Jews and Thrifty Chinese.”
It's all about the ethnic stereotypes of cheapness.

1012.text:
And my family's Jewish, and I always felt
that part of the way that people looked at

1017.text:
my father -- as kind of an eccentric and a
nut and totally cheap -- had something to

1022.text:
do with him being Jewish.
That there was a particular way of combining

1028.text:
those two qualities in him -- the cheapness
and the Jewishness.

1032.text:
So this was a really fun chapter to research
and then put together.

1038.text:
And so I'll just read the first couple of
pages of it.

1042.text:
[reading] In 1885, a theater group in New
York debuted a new comic play by Frank Eugene

1048.text:
Chase called, 'A Ready-Made Suit.' The play
revolved around a woman who's charged with

1052.text:
polygamy after marrying nine men in quick
succession.

1056.text:
During her trial, two Jews described as 'eminent
jobbers in secondhand clothes', appear in

1061.text:
court to testify.
As one of them explains to the jury, they

1064.text:
both married the defendant on the same day,
because quote, [in a thick accent] "He thinks

1068.text:
if we can get one wife between us, that will
be less expensive.”

1073.text:
The crowd no doubt roared in appreciation
of the joke.

1076.text:
They certainly would have understood the subtext.
By this time, the image of the stingy, grasping

1080.text:
Jewish merchant or pawnbroker was a familiar
one in American popular culture -- a staple

1085.text:
of dime novels, variety shows, humor magazines,
and newspaper editorials.

1089.text:
It's one that remains with us today, hardly
dulled by age or political correctness.

1093.text:
For instance, there's the popular joke about
how Moses received the Ten Commandments from

1098.text:
God.
One day God appears to a Babylonian and says,

1101.text:
"I have a commandment.
I'd like to give it to you.”

1103.text:
The Babylonian says, "What is it?”
And God says, "Thou shalt not steal.”

1107.text:
The Babylonian says, "No, thanks.”
So God goes over to an Egyptian and offers

1111.text:
him the same deal.
When the Egyptian hears what the commandment

1114.text:
is, he also turns it down.
Then God meets Moses and says, "I have a commandment

1118.text:
for you.”
Moses says, "How much is it going to cost

1123.text:
"Fine" says Moses, "I'll take ten.”
[laughter] It's funny.

1128.text:
There are countless variations on the theme.
Why did the Jews wander in the desert for

1131.text:
40 years?
Because one of them dropped a nickel.

1135.text:
What's a Jewish dilemma? Free pork.
I think they're funny.

1139.text:
Jews aren't the only ethnic group to have
been branded with the Scarlet Letter, C.

1145.text:
Go back in history and you'll find a glut
of accusations -- often muffled in humor,

1149.text:
sometimes loosed with open contempt -- by
one group that its neighbors or adversaries

1153.text:
are cheap or miserly or obsessed with money
and accumulation.

1157.text:
The English viewed the Scots as hopeless cheapskates,
while the Irish were written off as drunks

1161.text:
and spendthrifts.
The Dutch have a long reputation for being

1164.text:
tight with cash.
Ben Franklin himself popularized the rhyme,

1167.text:
"The thrifty maxim of the wary Dutch is to
save all the money they can touch.”

1172.text:
In America, Yankees -- members of old families
of New England -- were both admired and reviled

1177.text:
for their legendary thrift.
Scandinavians, Germans, and Japanese were

1181.text:
tagged as parsimonious by American writers.
And Westerners used up a great deal of ink

1185.text:
describing the frugal ways of Chinese living
in China and abroad.

1189.text:
Why have so many ethnic and national groups
been cast in the role of the world's tightwads?

1194.text:
The late Harvard psychologist, Gordon Allport
once said that "Stereotypes are projection

1199.text:
screens for modern man's anxieties," and this
one is no different.

1203.text:
The stereotypes of cheap Jews and thrifty
Chinese -- two of the most enduring examples,

1208.text:
and the ones I explore in this chapter -- reveal
more about the people broadcasting them than

1212.text:
they do about the real lives and practices
of Jews and Chinese people.

1215.text:
They tell us about the social, political and
economic worries that vexed Americans as they

1220.text:
commiserated over a lost job with friends
or headed off to the mines for work, or spent

1225.text:
their week's earnings at the grocery store.
And they tell us about the complicated emotions

1229.text:
that hovered under the surface in a free market
economy of winners and losers.

1233.text:
Emotions like envy, resentment, admiration,
fear, and -- perhaps most of all -- ambivalence.

1239.text:
Ambivalence about the promises of equality
and opportunity and meritocracy that were

1243.text:
advertised as the American dream.
These emotions bobbed up and fixed themselves

1248.text:
to the waves of immigrants who came to the
United States in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

1253.text:
Native-born Americans watched Jews and Chinese
gain a fragile, economic foothold in their

1258.text:
adopted country and interpreted that success
as a threat to their own property and job

1262.text:
opportunities.
And then, I kind of go on to detail where

1266.text:
both of those two stereotypes kind of originated
from -- which for Jews, it had a lot to do

1273.text:
with being closed out of other fields, like
glass-blowing and metalwork in the Middle

1282.text:
Ages, and being forced into jobs like being
bankers and lenders, because Christians were

1287.text:
forbidden to do that.
And so, that was sort of the origins of the

1290.text:
Shylock stereotype.
And then, I kind of traced Shylock as he comes

1293.text:
to America and gets expressed in a variety
of ways here.

1297.text:
And then, with the Chinese -- the thrifty
Chinese -- a lot of it had to do with the

1301.text:
Gold Rush, and the waves of immigrants that
came from China to America and had no families

1309.text:
here to support and often could live on lower
incomes than a lot of the white and native-born

1315.text:
workers.
So there are a lot of -- there is an amazing

1319.text:
amount of propaganda out there in the 1800s
about how Chinese people eat rats and mice

1324.text:
and live on rice.
Americans couldn't get the whole like -- that

1329.text:
there was no giant slab of meat and potatoes
and stuff like that.

1332.text:
So there was a lot of talk about Chinese people
eating rats and dogs and stuff like that,

1338.text:
